Award.AwardTitle: Design and Development: Workshop Proposal for Emerging Engineering Educators Making Academic Change Happen (E3 MACH)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Emerging engineering educators, including graduate students close to completion of their doctoral work, and assistant professors who are just entering their fields, face specific challenges as they begin their careers. As recent advertisements for engineering positions suggest, engineering departments seek out new engineering educators who can bring innovation to their campuses, from designing new programs to introducing and assessing new pedagogies. In many cases, emerging engineering educators are not ready to enact change at higher, institutional levels. A typical graduate education focuses on acquiring competence in disciplinary research and it does not prepare emerging engineering educators to comprehend the academic environments and resulting cultures, value systems and constraints. As a result, many emerging engineering educators do not feel empowered or capable of implementing academic change. Furthermore, successful change agents require skills, such as, for example, strategic thinking, obtaining buy-in, and creating strategic partnerships, that are not a part of conventional emerging educator experiences. Change strategies have been well documented in the literature of other disciplines, such as organizational psychology and behavior, but have not been brought into the conversation within STEM education in a rigorous, accessible way. The "Emerging Engineering Educators Making Academic Change Happen" workshop fills the need of emerging engineering educators for research-based skills development and assistance in creating a plan for change. Through targeted working sessions on specific topics (e.g. partnership development, generating buy-in, institutional context, and identity discovery), participants learn about different types of academic institutional contexts and value systems, the interplay of their professional identity with cultural contexts and the change-making process, and research-proven strategies for making large scale change happen at different types of academic institutions.

Emerging engineering educators who envision themselves as change agents should work to adopt the disposition and skills of a change agent. This workshop will help these educators start on their path as engineering education innovators who are more likely to positively impact their departments and programs. The workshop covers a number of themes, such as: Cultivating an Allied Community of Colleagues and Making Change Happen on Campus. Diverse hands-on activities are structured to enable participants to better understand the development of personal and professional identities with the established academic value systems and institutional contexts, and identify the unique opportunities and constraints of their individual academic environments to develop strategies for expanding and implementing visions of academic change. By fostering the development of these skills and mindsets in the very people who must lead change efforts, this workshop promotes meaningful change in STEM higher education. Engaging emerging engineering educators in the workshop highlights the importance of developing change skills early in their careers. As part of this research, emerging engineering educators will be interviewed about their current or future change projects and will be provided with mentors and support for their change activities. Mentorship will continue after the workshop is over and the participants' progress on their projects will be tracked as they implement the MACH change strategies they learned during the workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to develop and deliver the Emerging Engineering Educators Making Academic Change Happen (E3 MACH) workshop and to recruit twelve emerging engineering educators (defined as graduate students and early-career faculty and post-doctoral fellows) to attend the workshop and acquire research-based skills necessary to become successful change leaders in academia. Emerging educators face unique challenges when faced with bringing innovation to their schools, and this project aimed to help those educators be more effective so they can more successfully influence their departments and programs earlier in their career. The ultimate goal of the project was to empower emerging engineering educators to create successful change in academia by practicing research-based skills learned at the workshop.

The E3 MACH Workshop was a two-day workshop held on January 19-20, 2019 at Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology in Terre Haute, IN. Twelve participants were selected and fully funded to participate in the workshop, and they included graduate students, post-doctoral fellows and early-career assistant professors from a range of engineering fields, and a wide range of academic institutions.

The two-day workshop was organized around a number of hands-on activities where participants could practice research-based skills necessary for developing and implementing academic change. During the first day of the workshop, the focus was on helping participants understand better what academic change means, how institutional contexts influence change efforts, how to build momentum for change and sustain support for change over time. During the second day of the workshop, the focus was on helping participants understand themselves as change agents that must operate within specific institutional contexts and organizational cultures. A special emphasis was placed on practicing skills that would enable these novice change makers to navigate some challenges that they are likely to encounter during their effort to implement change. During the two days participants participated in hands-on sessions that ranged, among others, from identifying opportunities for change, understanding academia, gauging and sustaining support/influence, building momentum for change, obtaining buy-in, having difficult conversations, and developing a pitch for their projects.

All participants completed a pre-workshop and post-workshop survey, and participated in individual post-workshop interviews. The collected data suggested that participants had a very thorough understanding of the skills required of individuals who are successful change makers in academia, yet they felt unprepared themselves with respect to many of those skills. Data collected from surveys and interviews suggested that prior to the workshop participants lacked preparation for the practical steps necessary to deliver successful academic change. Collected data also suggested that they greatly appreciated the workshop for helping them understand that creating change is not a nebulous process but that it requires a strategic approach, and that novice educators can become successful change makers by practicing a few specific skills. Participants recognized that the workshop did not suddenly make them successful change agents, but it empowered them to continue building on the important skills. Those skills include, but are not limited to communicating about necessary change with different stakeholder groups, obtaining buy-in, gaining and sustaining support, establishing strategic partnerships, building and sustaining momentum for change, and conducting difficult conversations.

Participants of the workshop greatly appreciated the workbook and other provided materials that distilled a large amount of research-based findings about academic change and presented the material through activities that addressed many of the questions and concerns novice educators had. Workshop participants left our two-day workshop having a better understanding of the strategic process that is necessary to execute a successful change project, and with a better understanding of the contexts, cultures, opportunities, and barriers associated with implementing change in different academic institutions. Because of this workshop, participants will likely be better prepared to initiate change projects at their current or future institutions earlier in their careers.
